intro: Quercus toza var. normalis, commonly known as the common chestnut oak, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its elongated, acorn-like fruits that mature in the fall. The leaves are typically lobed and have a serrated margin, while the bark is rough and scaly. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in mixed hardwood forests. This species plays an important role in providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
